Paragraph: Abstract

Plan synthesis aims to generate a course of actions or policies to transit given
1

initial states to goal states, provided domain models that could be designed by
2

experts or learnt from training data or interactions with the world. Intrigued by the
3

claims of emergent planning capabilities in large language models (LLMs), works
4

have been proposed to investigate the planning effectiveness of LLMs, without
5

considering any utilization of off-the-shelf planning techniques in LLMs. In this
6

paper, we aim to further study the insight of the planning capability of LLMs
7

by investigating the roles of LLMs in off-the-shelf planning frameworks. To do
8

this, we investigate the effectiveness of embedding LLMs into one of the well-
9

known planning frameworks, graph-based planning, proposing a novel LLMs-based
10

planning framework with LLMs embedded in two levels of planning graphs, i.e.,
11

mutual constraints generation level and constraints solving level. We empirically
12

exhibit the effectiveness of our proposed framework in various planning domains.
13

1
Introduction
14

Plan synthesis aims to generate a course of actions or policies to transit given initial states to goal
15

states, provided domain models that could be designed by experts or learnt from training data [1]
16

or interactions with the world [10, 9]. It is a time- and space-consuming open issue in the planning
17

community [6]. Intrigued by the claims of emergent planning capabilities in large language models
18

(LLMs), works have been proposed to investigate the planning effectiveness of LLMs, without
19

considering any utilization of off-the-shelf planning techniques in LLMs [15]. As demonstrated by
20

[15], even in a seemingly simple common-sense domain like Blocksworld that humans usually find
21

easy to solve, LLMs are evaluated to be quite ineffective in planning autonomously.
22

An interesting result shown by [15] is when taking the solution generated by LLMs, which is incorrect,
23

as a seed plan to be repaired by an off-the-shelf planner, e.g., LPG [4], a significant improvement
24

in search steps can be attained over the result when an empty plan provided as a seed plan for the
25

planner. This indicates that LLMs can indeed provide some helpful information (e.g., in some sense
26

of heuristics) for planning, even though they cannot solve planning problems solely. Inspired by the
27

result of loosely using plans generated by LLMs as seed plans, we are curious if it is possible to “dig”
28

more helpful information from LLMs to assist planning deeply, e.g., by inserting LLMs into planning
29

frameworks. By doing this, we aim to answer the question: what roles can be played exactly by
30

LLMs in planning? Indeed, there have been attempts to explore off-the-shelf planning techniques to
31

help LLMs solving planning problems [12]. Similar to [15], they only view planners as black-boxes
32

without deepening the integration of LLMs in planning frameworks.
33

To do this, we investigate the effectiveness of embedding LLMs into one of the well-known planning
34

frameworks, graph-based planning [2]. We propose a novel LLMs-based planning framework with
35

LLMs embedded in two phases of the planning framework (namely LLMs4Plan). The first phase is
36

to propose promising actions in “action-levels” of the planning graph using LLMs. The second phase
37

is to propose non-mutual action sets using LLMs when backtracking the planning graph. Note that
38

the two phases correspond to two critical steps that influence the efficiency and effectiveness in graph
39

planning.
40

action set 2

For example, as shown in Figure 1(a), there
41

could be a large number of actions in “action-
42

level 1” when expanding “state-label 0” with
43

Graphplan [2]. We aim to exploit LLMs to help
44

select a small subset of promising actions, e.g.,
45

{a1, a2, a3} are selected in Figure 1(a). In Fig-
46

ure 1(b), when backtracking from “state-level K”
47

that includes goals, there could be a large num-
48

ber of candidate sets of actions to be explored
49

(e.g., “action set 1”, “action set 2”, “action set
50

3”) — actions in each candidate set are not mu-
51

tually exclusive with each other (two actions are
52

mutually exclusive if they are not allowed to be
53

executed at the same time, e.g., actions “pick up
54

object A” and “put down object A” are mutually
55

exclusive). It is particularly time-consuming to
56

search all of the valid candidate sets based on mutual constraints in each action-level. We expect
57

LLMs are capable of selecting a small number of candidate sets to be backtracked, e.g., only “action
58

set 1” is selected to be backtracked by LLMs as shown in Figure 1(b).
59

Specifically, in LLMs4Plan, for each action-level i, we first automatically generate prompts based
60

on propositions in state-level i −1, goals and domain models, and feed the prompts to LLMs to
61

select actions for generating action-level i. After that, when backtracking from the last state-level
62

K in the expanded planning graph, which includes the goal, we automatically generate prompts
63

based on propositions in state-level K, propositions in the initial state (i.e., state-level 0), mutual
64

constraints in action-level K, and domain models, and feed the prompts to LLMs to select action
65

sets for backtracking. We embed the above two components into one of the well-known off-the-shelf
66

graph planners, Graphplan [2]. We study the effectiveness of different cases of adding or removing
67

the above one or two components in Graphplan to see the significance of roles LLMs play in the
68

graph planning framework.
69

Through this study, we provide new clues for how to deeply embed LLMs into off-the-shelf planning
70

frameworks, i.e., first identifying critical steps (generally time-consuming ones) in specific planning
71

frameworks, and then designing proper prompt generation to be embedded into the frameworks. We
72

verify that soly relying on LLMs to do planning is far from a good option, while leveraging LLMs to
73

help deal with some critical steps in the graph planning framework is possible.
74

2
Problem Formulation
75

In this work we consider classical planning problems specified in the form of STRIPS [3]. Similar
76

ideas can be extended into more expressive planning language such as PDDL [5]. Let L be a set of
77

atoms, each of which is composed of a predicate with zero or more parameters (e.g., clean(room)
78

is an atom indicating room is clean). A STRIPS domain is composed of a set of action models A,
79

each of which is a quadruple ⟨a, PRE(a), ADD(a), DEL(a)⟩, where a is an action name with zero or
80

more parameters, PRE(a) ⊆L is a precondition list indicating the conditions under which a can be
81

applied, ADD(a) ⊆L is an adding list and DEL(a) ⊆L is a deleting list indicating the effects of a.
82

Let R be a set of propositions, which are instances of atoms in L. We define a planning problem as
83

P = ⟨R, s0, g, A⟩, where s0 ⊆R is an initial state and g ⊆R is a goal. A solution π to the planning
84

problem is a sequence of actions that transit initial state s0 to goal g. An intuitive example of our
85

planning problem is as shown below.
86

Suppose we would like to clean a bedroom using a vacuum which is placed in a tool room. We can for-
87

mulate the problem P = ⟨R, s0, g, A⟩in the form of STRIPS (note that we assume there is no parame-
88

ter for each predicate and action for simplicity since there is only one tool, one bedroom and one tool-
89

room). The set of propositions R is represented by R = {dirty(), toolroom(), clean(), bedroom()}.
90

Initial state s0 is represented by s0 = {dirty(), toolroom()}, which indicates the “bedroom” is
91

dirty, and the tool “vacuum” is in the tool room (i.e., “toolroom”). The goal g is represented by
92

g = {clean(), toolroom()}, which indicates the “bedroom” is clean, and the tool “vacuum” is back
93

to the tool room. The set of action models A is represented as follows:
94

Action
Preconditions
Effects
vacuum()
dirty(), bedroom()
clean(), ¬dirty()
move2tr()
bedroom()
toolroom(), ¬bedroom()
move2br()
toolroom()
bedroom(), ¬toolroom() 95

Action vacuum() aims to vacuuming “bedroom”, the preconditions of which are “bedroom” is
96

dirty and the vacuum-cleaner is in “bedroom”. The effects of vacuum() are adding clean() to
97

the state where vacuum() is executed, indicating “bedroom” is clean, and deleting dirty() (i.e.,
98

¬dirty()) from the state, indicating “bedroom” is not dirty anymore. Action move2tr() aims
99

to move the vacuum-cleaner to “toolroom”, the precondition of which is bedroom() indicating
100

the vacuum-cleaner is in “bedroom”. The effects are adding toolroom() indicating the vacuum-
101

cleaner is in “toolroom”, and deleting bedroom(), indicating the vacuum-cleaner is not in “bed-
102

room”. Similarly, action move2br aims to move the vacuum-cleaner to “bedroom”, the precondi-
103

tion of which is toolroom(), indicating the vacuum-cleaner is in “toolroom”. The effects are the
104

vacuum-cleaner is adding bedroom(), indicating the vacuum-cleaner is in “bedroom”, deleting
105

toolroom(), indicating the vacuum-cleaner is not in “toolroom”. A solution π to the problem P is
106

move2br(), vacuum(), move2tr().
107

3
Our LLMs4Plan approach
108

An overview of our LLMs4Plan approach is shown in Algorithm ??. In Step 3, the pruning possibility
109

κi is decreased as the exponent i increasing. In Step 5, we expand planning graph PGr with one
110

more level using LLMs to prune actions based on pruning possibility κi and planning problem
111

P. In Steps 7, if goal g is not included by the last state-level in PGr, i.e., Satisfied(g, PGr) is
112

false, we continue to Step 4. In Step 8, we build a set of mutual constraints C based on PGr, i.e.,
113

buildConstraints(PGr). In Step 9, we sort sets of actions based on constraints C using LLMs,
114

i.e., sortActionsLLMs(PGr, C. In Step 10, we search solution π based on the sorted action sets A
115
using depth-first search. In the following subsections, we will address our LLMs4Plan in detail.

Algorithm 1 An overview of our LLMs4Plan
Input: Planning problem P, pruning possibility κ0
Output: Solution π

1: PGr = ∅
2: for i = 1 to N do
3:
κi = (κ0)i, k = 1
4:
while k < K do
5:
PGr ←expandGraphLLMs(PGr, P, κi)
6:
k = k + 1
7:
if Satisfied(g, PGr) = false, then continue
8:
C = buildConstraints(PGr)
9:
A = sortActionsLLMs(PGr, C)
10:
π = depthFirstSearch(A, PGr)
11:
if π ̸= Failure, then return π
12:
end while
13: end for
14: return Failure 116

3.1
Building Planning Graphs with LLMs
117

A planning graph PGr is the search space for a relaxed version of the planning problem, an
118

intuitive framework of which is shown in Figure 5. It alternates layers of ground literals and
119

actions. “Square” nodes at action-level i + 1 indicate actions that might be possible to be exe-
120

cuted in state si. Maintenance actions indicate dump operators that keep literals unchanged be-
121

tween state-levels i and i + 1. “Black circle” nodes at state-level i indicate literals that might
122

possibly be true at time i.
Edges between state-level i and action-level i indicate literals in
123

state-level i are preconditions of actions in action-level i, while edges between action-level i and
124

state-level i + 1 indicate literals in state-level i + 1 are adding or deleting effects of actions in
125

action-level i. The nodes in the first state-level indicate literals that are true in initial state s0.
126 ... ...

action-level i+1 ...

lected by LLMs, are added into action-
137

138

sponding to each proposition in state-
139

level 0 is added into action-level 1.

3.2
Building Mutual Constraints
159

Due to the satisfaction of action models being relaxed, actions and/or
160

states in action-levels or state-labels may be inconsistent, i.e., there
161

may be some actions mutually exclusive in action-levels, or some literals mutually exclusive in
162

state-levels. As shown in Figure 4, there are three types of mutual exclusion constraints among
163

actions. Specifically, two actions at the same action-level are mutex, if they satisfy the following
164

conditions:
165

• An effect of one negates an effect of the other, which is called inconsistent effects.
166

• One deletes a precondition of the other, which is called interference.
167

• They have mutually exclusive preconditions, which is called Competing needs.
168

Otherwise they do not interfere with each other, i.e., both may appear in a solution plan. Two literals
169

at the same state-level are mutex if one is the negation of the other, or all ways of achieving them are
170

pairwise mutex, namely inconsistent support.
171

(a). inconsistent effects
(b). interference
(c). competing needs

4
Experiment
185

4.1
Experimental Setup
186

In the experiment, we evaluate LLMs4Plan in ten planning domains
187

with different scenarios, including gripper, miconic, logistics, movie, blocks, satellite, zenotravel,
188

driverlog, woodworking and openstacks. Ten problems are randomly selected for each domain. The
189

specific scenarios and sizes are described in Appendix A.1.
190

To demonstrate the effectiveness of our LLMs4Plan approach, we designed five sets of comparison
191

experiments. The methods were implemented using Python. We compared our LLMs4Plan approach
192

with four other methods, which are listed below:
193

• GP: It is the graph-based planning algorithm mentioned above. We implement the traditional
194

graph planning algorithm as the most important baseline for comparison. We directly provide
195

domain.pddl and problem.pddl to the planner for solving.
196

• GPT-3.5: We simply construct and splice the contents of domain.pddl and problem.pddl
197

directly. We then add the necessary command prompts to form a complete prompt into
198

GPT3.5 and command the model to solve the problem directly.
199

• GPT-4: The process is the same as GPT-3.5.
200

• LLMs4Plan-GPT3.5: When we are expanding the hierarchy or backtracking, we are faced
201

with a candidate action selection with LLMs. We guide the LLMs to select a minimal subset
202

of actions from them and utilize this subset of actions for the next algorithmic operations,
203

where LLMs are specifically GPT-3.5.
204

• LLMs4Plan-GPT4: Replaced the LLM model with GPT4, otherwise same as LLMs4Plan-
205

4.2
Experimental Metrics
207

In the experimental framework described, we employed three distinct metrics to assess the efficacy of
208

various methodologies: the problem-solving success rate, the cumulative count of expansion actions
209

and the node count for backtracking in Depth-First Search (DFS).
210

Problem-solving success rate. The solvability of a problem is a crucial metric in assessing planning
211

problems. All approaches are required to generate a sequence of actions that is sufficient to solve the
212

problem, and only if the problem can be transferred from the initial state to the goal state through
213

this sequence of actions can the corresponding problem be considered to be successfully solved.
214

Furthermore, we have established an upper bound on the depth of the problem-solving process.
215

The optimal length of the action sequence for the test problem is known to us. Should the solution
216

obtained surpass this predetermined depth, it signifies the inability of the method to successfully
217

ascertain the optimal action path for this particular problem. Setting an upper bound on the depth of
218

the problem-solving process serves the purpose of not only requiring the planner to solve problems
219

but also demanding that it does so more efficiently. This ensures that the output action sequences are
220

more concise and accurate, minimizing the occurrence of redundant actions.
221

Total number of expansion actions. In the GP algorithm, the expansion of actions at each layer is a
222

fundamental process, and the number of these expansions serves as a vital metric. Under the premise
223

of preserving effective actions, fewer expansions result in a reduced count of mutually exclusive
224

action pairs and subsequently fewer branches in the deep search phase of backtracking, thereby
225

enhancing efficiency. Consequently, we compute the average total number of action expansions per
226

layer across all problems, applying different methods within various domains, as a significant metric
227

for comparison.
228

Number of nodes for backtracking DFS. This metric serves as the cornerstone for validating our
229

optimization efforts, as the DFS during backtracking accounts for the majority of the computational
230

load in the GP algorithm, overshadowing the forward expansion phase. Particularly when dealing with
231

increasing expansion depths, the exponentially growing number of DFS poses the most significant
232

challenge for GP algorithms in tackling large-scale problems or complex solution sequences. We
233

primarily utilize this metric to ascertain which method truly enhances the efficiency of the planning
234

process.
235

Regarding the number of nodes for backtracking DFS, our analysis was confined to data from the
236

GP and LLMs4Plan-GPT4 methods, primarily for two reasons. Firstly, the metric is relevant only
237

in scenarios where the problem is successfully solved; failed solutions do not yield countable data.
238

Consequently, we excluded LLMs4Plan-GPT3.5 from our statistical analysis due to its comparatively
239

lower success rate. Secondly, these metrics are inherently calculable within the GP framework alone.
240

Hence, directly solving problems using GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 precludes the possibility of gathering
241

this data, as these methods operate outside the GP framework.
242

4.3
Experimental Results
243

We present the success rates in Table 1, depict the pruning effects of action expansion for LLM on
244

GP in Figure 7, and showcase experimental results in Table 2 comparing our approach to traditional
245

GP algorithms in terms of the number of nodes for backtracking DFS metrics, along with relevant
246

ablation studies.
247

Ablation Experiment: We conducted four ablation experiments to ascertain the effectiveness of
248

forward pruning and backward sorting, detailed as follows:
249

1. LLMs4Plan: This method involves both forward pruning and backward sorting.
250

2. LLMs4Plan-unsorted: Here, we implement pruning without sorting.
251

Table 1: Success rate results. In the table, each row corresponds to a distinct domain, while each
column represents a separate approach or method. The values presented within the table indicate the
success rate for each combination of domain and approach, with these rates quantified on a scale
ranging from 0 to 1.

3. LLMs4Plan-unpruned: In this approach, sorting is used, but not pruning.
252

4. GP: This method involves neither pruning nor sorting.
253

Table 2: In the table, each row corresponds to a distinct domain, while each column represents a
group of ablation experiments. The values presented within the table indicate the number of nodes
for backtracking DFS. Both pruning and sorting effectively enhance search efficiency, leading to a
substantial reduction in the number of nodes required for searching. Generally, pruning tends to be
slightly more effective than sorting.

4.4
Experimental Analysis
254

Analysis of the success rate of planning: From Table 1, several conclusions can be drawn. GPT3.5
255

exhibits competence primarily in resolving simple problems with short action sequence lengths, such
256

as in the movie domain, while its success rates are notably low in other domains. Consequently, it
257

struggles to enhance the capabilities of GP algorithms. Conversely, GPT4 demonstrates substantial
258

improvements in abilities compared to GPT3.5, particularly in reasoning skills and decision-making
259

involving long action sequences. With the enhanced reasoning and commonsense capabilities of
260

GPT4, GP shows an enhanced success rate in certain domains. We observe instances of failure in
261

GP, attributed to the inclusion of partially corrupt data during testing. Specifically, we introduce a
262

proportion of corrupted data by randomly removing action preconditions and effects propositions from
263

domain files. These instances have varying impacts across different domains, particularly affecting
264

traditional GP algorithms reliant on the completeness of domain files. We detail the influence of
265

random removal on success rates in Table 3. For each layer of GP expansion, the provision of action
266

preconditions and effects propositions is essential. However, in the case of LLM-augmented GP
267

algorithms, LLMs4Plan is capable of making rational action decisions even in the presence of missing
268

action propositions, thereby aiding in the completion of current planning tasks. Consequently, our
269

algorithm exhibits greater robustness in terms of success rates compared to traditional GP approaches.
270

The specific settings for the robustness experiments are detailed more extensively in section A.2 of
271

the appendix.
272

Table 3: This table illustrates experiments on the robustness of missing action predicates. In the
table, each row corresponds to a distinct domain. Each column in the table represents the proportion
of predicates we removed. A higher proportion indicates a greater amount of missing information,
posing increased difficulty for the planner to solve the problem. The values in the table represent
the success rates of GP in solving the problems. In the majority of domains, as the proportion of
deleted predicates increases, the success rate of GP planning decreases. Overall, this indicates that
GP exhibits poor robustness to missing action predicates.

Upon examining the generated action sequences, we observed that although GPT4 achieves a certain
273

level of success in solving problems, the action sequences it produces tend to be longer compared to
274

those generated by GP alone. By integrating GPT4 with graph planning, LLMs4Plan can effectively
275

generate more optimal action sequences.
276

Analysis of search efficiency: Besides planning success rates, our method significantly improves
277

search efficiency compared to GP algorithms. This enhancement is evident from Table 2, where,
278

among problems with successful planning outputs, we drastically reduce the cost of search nodes,
279

achieving an exponential level of optimization. So, how does the LLM-augmented GP method
280

enhance search efficiency?
281

Through in-depth analysis of experimental cases, we identify two main aspects of optimization:
282

1. During forward expansion, LLM efficiently and effectively prunes the expansion actions,
283

leading to varying degrees of stable reduction in the total number of expanded actions and
284

mutually exclusive actions. Consequently, the computational load of forward expansion
285

decreases correspondingly.
286

2. During the depth-first search backtracking process, LLM prioritizes searching closer to the
287

set of planning solutions, accelerating the attainment of planning solutions and saving time
288

by avoiding ineffective searches.
289

We provide an example from the ’logistics’ domain to illustrate our analysis in Figure 7, where we
290

compare the number of expansion actions before and after LLM pruning. The application of LLM
291

for pruning demonstrates significant efficacy across all layers. In addition, we have provided further
292

experimental results and analysis on the total number of mutually exclusive actions and expanded
293

actions in section A.3 of the supplementary materials.
294

For pruning, the greatest risk is removing necessary actions, rendering the problem unsolvable. In
295

our experiments, we observed instances where LLM prunes crucial actions in certain layers, resulting
296

in the inability to obtain effective solutions. However, we introduced pruning probabilities to ensure
297

algorithm completeness. Experimental results demonstrate that although the process of correcting
298

LLM’s erroneous pruning behavior through pruning probabilities may introduce additional expansion
299

and search steps, the cumulative cost of these search steps remains significantly lower than the cost of
300

solely using GP algorithms to solve problems. The results presented in Table 2 compare the outcomes
301

of our method LLMs4Plan, which ensures completeness, with those of GP algorithms.
302

Analysis of ablation experiments: Table 2 reveals that both pruning and sorting contribute to
303

enhanced search efficiency, with their combination amplifying this effect. Notably, pruning appears
304

slightly more effective than sorting. This is likely because LLM, while pruning, also organizes the
305

remaining actions logically. In contrast, sorting may lead to minor errors due to the multitude of
306

actions and lengthy text. In this regard, we require further optimization of natural language processing
307

Figure 7: An example of action pruning. Both the GP and LLMs4Plan-GPT4 methods expanded
through 10 layers. The horizontal axis represents the layer number, with lower numbers indicating
proximity to the initial state and higher numbers nearing the goal state. The vertical axis shows the
count of expanded actions, including both domain-specific actions and numerous empty actions,
characteristic of the graph planning algorithm. This implies a high pruning ratio for genuinely
effective actions. LLMs prune almost every layer of expansion actions and the data in the table also
contains many empty actions.

techniques tailored for handling extremely long texts to enhance our framework’s capability in solving
308

more complex problems. The experiments also indicate that LLM tends not to prioritize empty actions
309

in graph planning, favoring their later arrangement. This aligns with our analysis suggesting that
310

prioritizing non-empty actions is more productive, as a layer without any action is essentially
311

redundant.
312

Analysis of the advantages and disadvantages of LLMs4Plan: Upon analyzing examples where
313

solutions failed, we observed that GPT4 is more prone to pruning errors at deeper expansion levels.
314

This results in the discarding of effective actions, thereby unnecessarily increasing the expansion
315

layers and hindering problem resolution. We attribute this to two primary factors. Firstly, as the
316

expansion level deepens, both the predicate set and the candidate action set expand, leading to
317

increasingly lengthy input prompts. This prolonged text can cause GPT-4 to gradually lose track of
318

previous information, resulting in decision-making errors. Secondly, the nature of the predicate set in
319

graph planning diverges from traditional planning’s current state representation. This discrepancy
320

impairs LLM’s ability to accurately analyze the predicate set, leading to the erroneous elimination of
321

effective actions. LLM lacks capacity to analyze complex predicate set combinations.
322

Our analysis of additional failure examples indicates that graph planning excels in efficiently handling
323

numerous non-mutually exclusive actions in parallel, due to its ability to group these actions within
324

the same layer. However, its limitation becomes apparent in scenarios requiring the execution of
325

highly complex and extremely long action sequences. If a problem’s optimal solution sequences are
326

lengthy, the planning graph must be expanded considerably deeper. Despite effective pruning, this
327

does not resolve the issue of exponential complexity growth in backtracking DFS caused by increased
328

depth.
329

5
Conclusion and Future Work
330

Our comparative experiments in multiple domains demonstrated the efficacy of our LLMs4Plan in
331

significantly enhancing the problem-solving capabilities of graph planning algorithms. Notably,
332

LLMs4Plan boosts not just the success rate of problem resolution but also markedly enhances search
333

efficiency and substantially reduces computational complexity.
The runtime of LLMs4Plan is
334

currently hindered by multiple LLMs calls. While our method requires multiple LLMs calls, it
335

provides substantially improved results. There are also various ways to enhance runtime performance
336

like using smaller LLMs like Llama [14] or distilling LLMs’ knowledge into a smaller model
337

[13, 7, 11]. Those are interesting avenues for future research. Instead of leveraging LLMs to
338

assist planning, it would also be possible to study acquring action models [16] and more planning
339

frameworks [8] with the help of LLMs.
340

A
Appendix / supplemental material
394

A.1
Description of Testing Domains
395

In the experiment, we evaluate LLMs4Plan in ten planning domains with different scenarios, in-
396

cluding gripper, miconic, logistics, movie, blocks, satellite, zenotravel, driverlog, woodworking and
397

openstacks, which are:
398

• Gripper: Tasks utilize an existing robot arm to move objects between rooms, with between
399

6 and 20 objects in the scene.
400

• Miconic: Tasks uses elevators to serve guests between floors and help them reach the floor
401

they want to go to, with between 6 and 50 objects in the scene.
402

• Logistics: One of the classic logistics problems. Transportation of items between different
403

locations in different cities using trucks and airplanes, with between 10 and 30 objects in
404

the scenario.
405

• Movie: Simulate some simple behaviors while watching a movie with between 45 and 155
406

objects in the scene.
407

• Blocks: As one of the most classic planning problems, it involves manipulating various
408

blocks on a table using a robotic arm to achieve specific goals. The number of blocks in the
409

scenario ranges between 20 and 40.
410

• Satellite: Satellites equipped with various instruments perform different tasks in space. The
411

total number of entities, including instruments and satellites, ranges from 20 to 40.
412

• Zenotravel: This field involves the problem of passengers traveling between different cities
413

by airplane, including the management of aircraft fuel. The total number of entities in the
414

scenario ranges from 20 to 30.
415

• Driverlog: Different truck drivers need to coordinate the transportation of goods between
416

platforms using trucks. The total number of entities in the scenario ranges from 20 to 30.
417

• Woodworking: A carpenter needs to operate various machines, wooden boards, and com-
418

ponents in the workshop to complete processing tasks. The total number of entities in the
419

scenario ranges from 30 to 40.
420

• Openstacks: In an assembly line, the corresponding number of products are produced based
421

on order tasks. The total number of entities in the scenario ranges from 10 to 30.
422

A.2
Robustness Experimental Setup
423

In the robustness experiments in Table 3, we randomly delete a certain proportion (e.g., 10%,
424

20%, 30%, 40%, 50%) of action preconditions and effects propositions (referred to collectively as
425

conditions) from the domain files and assess whether the GP algorithm can produce correct solutions.
426

We conduct five sets of experiments for each proportion in every domain, with each experiment tested
427

three times to obtain the average success rate. In addition to the previously defined criteria, failures
428

also include cases where the GP algorithm may become stuck in a loop or program deadlock due to
429

missing predicates. Therefore, we set an extended time threshold. If the solving process exceeds this
430

threshold, we consider it as a failed solution. Timeliness in planning is crucial; if a problem remains
431

unsolved for several times the normal solving duration, the planner becomes impractical.
432

A.3
Additional Experiments
433

In this section, our primary focus lies in elucidating the fundamental reasons behind the efficiency of
434

our algorithm compared to the GP algorithm. In this section, our primary objective is to delve into
435

the fundamental reasons underlying the efficiency of our algorithm in contrast to the GP algorithm.
436

To commence, we will elucidate two evaluation metrics: the total number of expansion actions and
437

the total number of mutually exclusive actions.
438

Total number of expansion actions. In the GP algorithm, the expansion of actions at each layer is a
439

fundamental process, and the number of these expansions serves as a vital metric. Under the premise
440

of preserving effective actions, fewer expansions result in a reduced count of mutually exclusive
441

action pairs and subsequently fewer branches in the deep search phase of backtracking, thereby
442

enhancing efficiency. Consequently, we compute the average total number of action expansions per
443

layer across all problems, applying different methods within various domains, as a significant metric
444

for comparison.
445

Total number of mutually exclusive actions. Mutually exclusive actions are generated from the set
446

of candidate expansion actions based on many different mutually exclusive conditions. The critical
447

aspect of this metric lies in the fact that a lower total number of mutually exclusive actions translates
448

into significant computational time savings. This efficiency is evident both during the generation of
449

the mutually exclusive action set in the forward expansion phase and in the filtering of candidate
450

actions based on this set during the backtracking process.
451

We conducted statistical analysis on relevant metrics for several domains, and the results are presented
452

in Table 4. The data indicates that both the total number of expansion actions and mutually exclusive
453

actions experience a consistent decline with LLM integration. This suggests a reduction in the
454

computational effort required for forward expansion. Overall, these data corroborate the conclusion
455

drawn from our experimental analysis regarding the efficiency of LLMs4Plan.
456

Table 4: LLM pruning results. In the table, each column signifies a distinct domain. It displays the
statistical outcomes of the two methods across two indicators. Smaller numbers in the table denote
lower computational resource usage and greater effectiveness.

A.4
Experimental Case Presentation
457

In this section, we will present a specific case to illustrate how we integrate LLM into the GP
458

algorithm. This particular case is drawn from a problem in logistics domain. In our demonstration,
459

we will present three sets of actions at each layer involved in addressing this problem. The first set of
460

actions pertains to graph planning expansion and backtracking, denoted as the GP-ACTION-SET.
461

The second set of actions corresponds to the expansion process of the Large Language Model (LLM),
462

designated as the LLM-EP-ACTION-SET. The third set of actions relates to the backtracking process
463

of the LLM, termed as the LLM-BP-ACTION-SET.
464

The domain of logistics is described in PDDL language as follows:
465

(define (domain logistics-strips)
(:requirements :strips)
(:predicates (OBJ ?obj) (TRUCK ?truck) (LOCATION ?loc) (AIRPLANE ?airplane)
(CITY ?city) (AIRPORT ?airport) (at ?obj ?loc) (in ?obj1 ?obj2) (in-city ?obj ?city))

(:action LOAD-TRUCK
:parameters (?obj ?truck ?loc)
:precondition (and (OBJ ?obj) (TRUCK ?truck) (LOCATION ?loc) (at ?truck ?loc) (at ?obj
?loc))
:effect (and (not (at ?obj ?loc)) (in ?obj ?truck)))

(:action LOAD-AIRPLANE
:parameters (?obj ?airplane ?loc)
:precondition (and (OBJ ?obj) (AIRPLANE ?airplane) (LOCATION ?loc) (at ?obj ?loc) (at
?airplane ?loc))
:effect (and (not (at ?obj ?loc)) (in ?obj ?airplane)))

(:action UNLOAD-TRUCK
:parameters (?obj ?truck ?loc)
:precondition (and (OBJ ?obj) (TRUCK ?truck) (LOCATION ?loc) (at ?truck ?loc) (in ?obj
?truck))
:effect (and (not (in ?obj ?truck)) (at ?obj ?loc)))

(:action UNLOAD-AIRPLANE
:parameters (?obj ?airplane ?loc)
:precondition (and (OBJ ?obj) (AIRPLANE ?airplane) (LOCATION ?loc) (in ?obj
?airplane) (at ?airplane ?loc))
:effect (and (not (in ?obj ?airplane)) (at ?obj ?loc)))

(:action DRIVE-TRUCK
:parameters (?truck ?loc-from ?loc-to ?city)
:precondition (and (TRUCK ?truck) (LOCATION ?loc-from) (LOCATION ?loc-to) (CITY
?city) (at ?truck ?loc-from) (in-city ?loc-from ?city) (in-city ?loc-to ?city))
:effect (and (not (at ?truck ?loc-from)) (at ?truck ?loc-to)))

(:action FLY-AIRPLANE
:parameters (?airplane ?loc-from ?loc-to)
:precondition (and (AIRPLANE ?airplane) (AIRPORT ?loc-from) (AIRPORT ?loc-to) (at
?airplane ?loc-from))
:effect (and (not (at ?airplane ?loc-from)) (at ?airplane ?loc-to)))) 466

The problem of logistics is described in PDDL language as follows:
467

(define (problem logistics-02)
(:domain logistics-strips)
(:objects
a0
c0 c1
t0 t1
l00 l01 l10 l11
p0 p1
)
(:init
(AIRPLANE a0) (CITY c0) (CITY c1) (TRUCK t0) (TRUCK t1) (LOCATION l00) (in-city
l00 c0) (LOCATION l01) (in-city l01 c0) (LOCATION l10) (in-city l10 c1) (LOCATION
l11) (in-city l11 c1) (AIRPORT l00) (AIRPORT l10) (at a0 l00) (OBJ p0) (OBJ p1) (at t0
l00) (at t1 l10) (at p0 l01) )
(:goal
(and (at p0 l11) ) )
) 468

the final output of the planning solution with bold fonts. The first layer represents the initial expansion

action layer, and so on up to the final goal layer, totaling 10 layers.From this specific case, we can

observe the following points:
472

1. Although LLM undergoes pruning, the correct planning solution always exists within the
473

LLM-EP-ACTION-SET, with the removed actions being redundant.
474

2. The size of the LLM-EP-ACTION-SET is always smaller than that of the GP-ACTION-SET.
475

3. In the LLM-BP-ACTION-SET, LLM consistently positions the correct planning solution
476

actions towards the front among most other actions. Although not always the first, they are
477

generally placed near the beginning.

NeurIPS Paper Checklist
553

The checklist is designed to encourage best practices for responsible machine learning research,
554

addressing issues of reproducibility, transparency, research ethics, and societal impact. Do not remove
555

the checklist: The papers not including the checklist will be desk rejected. The checklist should
556

follow the references and follow the (optional) supplemental material. The checklist does NOT count
557

towards the page limit.
558

Please read the checklist guidelines carefully for information on how to answer these questions. For
559

each question in the checklist:
560

• You should answer [Yes] , [No] , or [NA] .
561

• [NA] means either that the question is Not Applicable for that particular paper or the
562

relevant information is Not Available.
563

• Please provide a short (1–2 sentence) justification right after your answer (even for NA).
564

The checklist answers are an integral part of your paper submission. They are visible to the
565

reviewers, area chairs, senior area chairs, and ethics reviewers. You will be asked to also include it
566

(after eventual revisions) with the final version of your paper, and its final version will be published
567

with the paper.
568

The reviewers of your paper will be asked to use the checklist as one of the factors in their evaluation.
569

While "[Yes] " is generally preferable to "[No] ", it is perfectly acceptable to answer "[No] " provided a
570

proper justification is given (e.g., "error bars are not reported because it would be too computationally
571

expensive" or "we were unable to find the license for the dataset we used"). In general, answering
572

"[No] " or "[NA] " is not grounds for rejection. While the questions are phrased in a binary way, we
573

acknowledge that the true answer is often more nuanced, so please just use your best judgment and
574

write a justification to elaborate. All supporting evidence can appear either in the main paper or the
575

supplemental material, provided in appendix. If you answer [Yes] to a question, in the justification
576

please point to the section(s) where related material for the question can be found.
577

IMPORTANT, please:
578

• Delete this instruction block, but keep the section heading “NeurIPS paper checklist",
579

• Keep the checklist subsection headings, questions/answers and guidelines below.
580

• Do not modify the questions and only use the provided macros for your answers.
581

1. Claims
582

Question: Do the main claims made in the abstract and introduction accurately reflect the
583

paper’s contributions and scope?
584

Answer: [Yes]
585

Justification:
586

Guidelines:
587

• The answer NA means that the abstract and introduction do not include the claims
588

made in the paper.
589

• The abstract and/or introduction should clearly state the claims made, including the
590

contributions made in the paper and important assumptions and limitations. A No or
591

NA answer to this question will not be perceived well by the reviewers.
592

• The claims made should match theoretical and experimental results, and reflect how
593

much the results can be expected to generalize to other settings.
594

• It is fine to include aspirational goals as motivation as long as it is clear that these goals
595

are not attained by the paper.
596

2. Limitations
597

Question: Does the paper discuss the limitations of the work performed by the authors?
598

Answer: [Yes]
599

Justification:
600

Guidelines:
601

• The answer NA means that the paper has no limitation while the answer No means that
602

the paper has limitations, but those are not discussed in the paper.
603

• The authors are encouraged to create a separate "Limitations" section in their paper.
604

• The paper should point out any strong assumptions and how robust the results are to
605

violations of these assumptions (e.g., independence assumptions, noiseless settings,
606

model well-specification, asymptotic approximations only holding locally). The authors
607

should reflect on how these assumptions might be violated in practice and what the
608

implications would be.
609

• The authors should reflect on the scope of the claims made, e.g., if the approach was
610

only tested on a few datasets or with a few runs. In general, empirical results often
611

depend on implicit assumptions, which should be articulated.
612

• The authors should reflect on the factors that influence the performance of the approach.
613

For example, a facial recognition algorithm may perform poorly when image resolution
614

is low or images are taken in low lighting. Or a speech-to-text system might not be
615

used reliably to provide closed captions for online lectures because it fails to handle
616

technical jargon.
617

• The authors should discuss the computational efficiency of the proposed algorithms
618

and how they scale with dataset size.
619

• If applicable, the authors should discuss possible limitations of their approach to
620

address problems of privacy and fairness.
621

• While the authors might fear that complete honesty about limitations might be used by
622

reviewers as grounds for rejection, a worse outcome might be that reviewers discover
623

limitations that aren’t acknowledged in the paper. The authors should use their best
624

judgment and recognize that individual actions in favor of transparency play an impor-
625

tant role in developing norms that preserve the integrity of the community. Reviewers
626

will be specifically instructed to not penalize honesty concerning limitations.
627

3. Theory Assumptions and Proofs
628

Question: For each theoretical result, does the paper provide the full set of assumptions and
629

a complete (and correct) proof?
630

Answer: [Yes]
631

Justification:
632

Guidelines:
633

• The answer NA means that the paper does not include theoretical results.
634

• All the theorems, formulas, and proofs in the paper should be numbered and cross-
635

referenced.
636

• All assumptions should be clearly stated or referenced in the statement of any theorems.
637

• The proofs can either appear in the main paper or the supplemental material, but if
638

they appear in the supplemental material, the authors are encouraged to provide a short
639

proof sketch to provide intuition.
640

• Inversely, any informal proof provided in the core of the paper should be complemented
641

by formal proofs provided in appendix or supplemental material.
642

• Theorems and Lemmas that the proof relies upon should be properly referenced.
643

4. Experimental Result Reproducibility
644

Question: Does the paper fully disclose all the information needed to reproduce the main ex-
645

perimental results of the paper to the extent that it affects the main claims and/or conclusions
646

of the paper (regardless of whether the code and data are provided or not)?
647

Answer: [Yes]
648

Justification:
649

Guidelines:
650

• The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.
651

• If the paper includes experiments, a No answer to this question will not be perceived
652

well by the reviewers: Making the paper reproducible is important, regardless of
653

whether the code and data are provided or not.
654

• If the contribution is a dataset and/or model, the authors should describe the steps taken
655

to make their results reproducible or verifiable.
656

• Depending on the contribution, reproducibility can be accomplished in various ways.
657

For example, if the contribution is a novel architecture, describing the architecture fully
658

might suffice, or if the contribution is a specific model and empirical evaluation, it may
659

be necessary to either make it possible for others to replicate the model with the same
660

dataset, or provide access to the model. In general. releasing code and data is often
661

one good way to accomplish this, but reproducibility can also be provided via detailed
662

instructions for how to replicate the results, access to a hosted model (e.g., in the case
663

of a large language model), releasing of a model checkpoint, or other means that are
664

appropriate to the research performed.
665

• While NeurIPS does not require releasing code, the conference does require all submis-
666

sions to provide some reasonable avenue for reproducibility, which may depend on the
667

nature of the contribution. For example
668

(a) If the contribution is primarily a new algorithm, the paper should make it clear how
669

to reproduce that algorithm.
670

(b) If the contribution is primarily a new model architecture, the paper should describe
671

the architecture clearly and fully.
672

(c) If the contribution is a new model (e.g., a large language model), then there should
673

either be a way to access this model for reproducing the results or a way to reproduce
674

the model (e.g., with an open-source dataset or instructions for how to construct
675

the dataset).
676

(d) We recognize that reproducibility may be tricky in some cases, in which case
677

authors are welcome to describe the particular way they provide for reproducibility.
678

In the case of closed-source models, it may be that access to the model is limited in
679

some way (e.g., to registered users), but it should be possible for other researchers
680

to have some path to reproducing or verifying the results.
681

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
5. Open access to data and code
682

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Question: Does the paper provide open access to the data and code, with sufficient instruc-
683

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
tions to faithfully reproduce the main experimental results, as described in supplemental
684

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
material?
685

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Answer: [Yes]
686

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Justification:
687

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Guidelines:
688

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The answer NA means that paper does not include experiments requiring code.
689

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• Please see the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https://nips.cc/
690

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.
691

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• While we encourage the release of code and data, we understand that this might not be
692

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
possible, so “No” is an acceptable answer. Papers cannot be rejected simply for not
693

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
including code, unless this is central to the contribution (e.g., for a new open-source
694

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
benchmark).
695

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The instructions should contain the exact command and environment needed to run to
696

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
reproduce the results. See the NeurIPS code and data submission guidelines (https:
697

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
//nips.cc/public/guides/CodeSubmissionPolicy) for more details.
698

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The authors should provide instructions on data access and preparation, including how
699

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
to access the raw data, preprocessed data, intermediate data, and generated data, etc.
700

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The authors should provide scripts to reproduce all experimental results for the new
701

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
proposed method and baselines. If only a subset of experiments are reproducible, they
702

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
should state which ones are omitted from the script and why.
703

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• At submission time, to preserve anonymity, the authors should release anonymized
704

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
versions (if applicable).
705

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• Providing as much information as possible in supplemental material (appended to the
706

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
paper) is recommended, but including URLs to data and code is permitted.
707

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
6. Experimental Setting/Details
708

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Question: Does the paper specify all the training and test details (e.g., data splits, hyper-
709

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
parameters, how they were chosen, type of optimizer, etc.) necessary to understand the
710

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
results?
711

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Answer: [Yes]
712

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Justification:
713

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
Guidelines:
714

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.
715

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The experimental setting should be presented in the core of the paper to a level of detail
716

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
that is necessary to appreciate the results and make sense of them.
717

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
• The full details can be provided either with the code, in appendix, or as supplemental
718

Section: OPEN ACCESS TO DATA AND CODE
Paragraph:
material.
719

7. Experiment Statistical Significance
720

Question: Does the paper report error bars suitably and correctly defined or other appropriate
721

information about the statistical significance of the experiments?
722

Answer: [Yes]
723

Justification:
724

Guidelines:
725

• The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.
726

• The authors should answer "Yes" if the results are accompanied by error bars, confi-
727

dence intervals, or statistical significance tests, at least for the experiments that support
728

the main claims of the paper.
729

• The factors of variability that the error bars are capturing should be clearly stated (for
730

example, train/test split, initialization, random drawing of some parameter, or overall
731

run with given experimental conditions).
732

• The method for calculating the error bars should be explained (closed form formula,
733

call to a library function, bootstrap, etc.)
734

• The assumptions made should be given (e.g., Normally distributed errors).
735

• It should be clear whether the error bar is the standard deviation or the standard error
736

of the mean.
737

• It is OK to report 1-sigma error bars, but one should state it. The authors should
738

preferably report a 2-sigma error bar than state that they have a 96% CI, if the hypothesis
739

of Normality of errors is not verified.
740

• For asymmetric distributions, the authors should be careful not to show in tables or
741

figures symmetric error bars that would yield results that are out of range (e.g. negative
742

error rates).
743

• If error bars are reported in tables or plots, The authors should explain in the text how
744

they were calculated and reference the corresponding figures or tables in the text.
745

8. Experiments Compute Resources
746

Question: For each experiment, does the paper provide sufficient information on the com-
747

puter resources (type of compute workers, memory, time of execution) needed to reproduce
748

the experiments?
749

Answer: [Yes]
750

Justification:
751

Guidelines:
752

• The answer NA means that the paper does not include experiments.
753

• The paper should indicate the type of compute workers CPU or GPU, internal cluster,
754

or cloud provider, including relevant memory and storage.
755

• The paper should provide the amount of compute required for each of the individual
756

experimental runs as well as estimate the total compute.
757

• The paper should disclose whether the full research project required more compute
758

than the experiments reported in the paper (e.g., preliminary or failed experiments that
759

didn’t make it into the paper).
760

9. Code Of Ethics
761

Question: Does the research conducted in the paper conform, in every respect, with the
762

NeurIPS Code of Ethics https://neurips.cc/public/EthicsGuidelines?
763

Answer: [Yes]
764

Justification:
765

Guidelines:
766

• The answer NA means that the authors have not reviewed the NeurIPS Code of Ethics.
767

• If the authors answer No, they should explain the special circumstances that require a
768

deviation from the Code of Ethics.
769

• The authors should make sure to preserve anonymity (e.g., if there is a special consid-
770

eration due to laws or regulations in their jurisdiction).
771

10. Broader Impacts
772

Question: Does the paper discuss both potential positive societal impacts and negative
773

societal impacts of the work performed?
774

Answer: [Yes]
775

Justification:
776

Guidelines:
777

• The answer NA means that there is no societal impact of the work performed.
778

• If the authors answer NA or No, they should explain why their work has no societal
779

impact or why the paper does not address societal impact.
780

• Examples of negative societal impacts include potential malicious or unintended uses
781

(e.g., disinformation, generating fake profiles, surveillance), fairness considerations
782

(e.g., deployment of technologies that could make decisions that unfairly impact specific
783

groups), privacy considerations, and security considerations.
784

• The conference expects that many papers will be foundational research and not tied
785

to particular applications, let alone deployments. However, if there is a direct path to
786

any negative applications, the authors should point it out. For example, it is legitimate
787

to point out that an improvement in the quality of generative models could be used to
788

generate deepfakes for disinformation. On the other hand, it is not needed to point out
789

that a generic algorithm for optimizing neural networks could enable people to train
790

models that generate Deepfakes faster.
791

• The authors should consider possible harms that could arise when the technology is
792

being used as intended and functioning correctly, harms that could arise when the
793

technology is being used as intended but gives incorrect results, and harms following
794

from (intentional or unintentional) misuse of the technology.
795

• If there are negative societal impacts, the authors could also discuss possible mitigation
796

strategies (e.g., gated release of models, providing defenses in addition to attacks,
797

mechanisms for monitoring misuse, mechanisms to monitor how a system learns from
798

feedback over time, improving the efficiency and accessibility of ML).
799

11. Safeguards
800

Question: Does the paper describe safeguards that have been put in place for responsible
801

release of data or models that have a high risk for misuse (e.g., pretrained language models,
802

image generators, or scraped datasets)?
803

Answer: [Yes]
804

Justification:
805

Guidelines:
806

• The answer NA means that the paper poses no such risks.
807

• Released models that have a high risk for misuse or dual-use should be released with
808

necessary safeguards to allow for controlled use of the model, for example by requiring
809

that users adhere to usage guidelines or restrictions to access the model or implementing
810

safety filters.
811

• Datasets that have been scraped from the Internet could pose safety risks. The authors
812

should describe how they avoided releasing unsafe images.
813

• We recognize that providing effective safeguards is challenging, and many papers do
814

not require this, but we encourage authors to take this into account and make a best
815

faith effort.
816

12. Licenses for existing assets
817

Question: Are the creators or original owners of assets (e.g., code, data, models), used in
818

the paper, properly credited and are the license and terms of use explicitly mentioned and
819

properly respected?
820

Answer: [Yes]
821

Justification:
822

Guidelines:
823

• The answer NA means that the paper does not use existing assets.
824

• The authors should cite the original paper that produced the code package or dataset.
825

• The authors should state which version of the asset is used and, if possible, include a
826

URL.
827

• The name of the license (e.g., CC-BY 4.0) should be included for each asset.
828

• For scraped data from a particular source (e.g., website), the copyright and terms of
829

service of that source should be provided.
830

• If assets are released, the license, copyright information, and terms of use in the
831

package should be provided. For popular datasets, paperswithcode.com/datasets
832

has curated licenses for some datasets. Their licensing guide can help determine the
833

license of a dataset.
834

• For existing datasets that are re-packaged, both the original license and the license of
835

the derived asset (if it has changed) should be provided.
836

• If this information is not available online, the authors are encouraged to reach out to
837

the asset’s creators.
838

13. New Assets
839

Question: Are new assets introduced in the paper well documented and is the documentation
840

provided alongside the assets?
841

Answer: [Yes]
842

Justification:
843

Guidelines:
844

• The answer NA means that the paper does not release new assets.
845

• Researchers should communicate the details of the dataset/code/model as part of their
846

submissions via structured templates. This includes details about training, license,
847

limitations, etc.
848

• The paper should discuss whether and how consent was obtained from people whose
849

asset is used.
850

• At submission time, remember to anonymize your assets (if applicable). You can either
851

create an anonymized URL or include an anonymized zip file.
852

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
14. Crowdsourcing and Research with Human Subjects
853

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Question: For crowdsourcing experiments and research with human subjects, does the paper
854

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
include the full text of instructions given to participants and screenshots, if applicable, as
855

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
well as details about compensation (if any)?
856

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Answer: [Yes]
857

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Justification:
858

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Guidelines:
859

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• The answer NA means that the paper does not involve crowdsourcing nor research with
860

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
human subjects.
861

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• Including this information in the supplemental material is fine, but if the main contribu-
862

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
tion of the paper involves human subjects, then as much detail as possible should be
863

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
included in the main paper.
864

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• According to the NeurIPS Code of Ethics, workers involved in data collection, curation,
865

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
or other labor should be paid at least the minimum wage in the country of the data
866

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
collector.
867

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
15. Institutional Review Board (IRB) Approvals or Equivalent for Research with Human
868

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Subjects
869

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Question: Does the paper describe potential risks incurred by study participants, whether
870

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
such risks were disclosed to the subjects, and whether Institutional Review Board (IRB)
871

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
approvals (or an equivalent approval/review based on the requirements of your country or
872

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
institution) were obtained?
873

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Answer: [Yes]
874

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Justification:
875

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
Guidelines:
876

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• The answer NA means that the paper does not involve crowdsourcing nor research with
877

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
human subjects.
878

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• Depending on the country in which research is conducted, IRB approval (or equivalent)
879

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
may be required for any human subjects research. If you obtained IRB approval, you
880

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
should clearly state this in the paper.
881

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• We recognize that the procedures for this may vary significantly between institutions
882

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
and locations, and we expect authors to adhere to the NeurIPS Code of Ethics and the
883

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
guidelines for their institution.
884

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
• For initial submissions, do not include any information that would break anonymity (if
885

Section: CROWDSOURCING AND RESEARCH WITH HUMAN SUBJECTS
Paragraph:
applicable), such as the institution conducting the review.
886
